title: Worksheet 3: Making Things Repeat
description: Learn to use for loops to repeat actions and create cool visual patterns and fun programs.

problems.title: The problem with repetition
problems.content: Sometimes we want to do the same thing over and over. Typing it all out is a lot of work!
problems.task: Run this code to see 'Hello' printed five times.
problems.hint: Just press the 'Run Code' button to see the output.

problems.title: A better way: the for loop
problems.content: A for loop is a special command that repeats a block of code. Here, the code print('Hello') is run for each number in the list [1, 2, 3, 4, 5].
problems.task: Run the code to see the loop in action.
problems.hint: The loop does the hard work of repeating the print command for you.

problems.title: Modify the loop
problems.content: The list in the for loop controls how many times it repeats.
problems.task: Edit the list so the loop only repeats three times.
problems.hint: Make the list shorter! It should only contain three numbers, like [1, 2, 3].

problems.title: Meet the loop variable
problems.content: The variable in the loop (we called it number here) holds the value of each item in the list, one by one.
problems.task: Run the code to see how the number variable changes on each repetition.
problems.hint: The loop will first set number to 1 and print it, then 2, then 3.

problems.title: Your Own Number Sequence
problems.content: You can put any numbers you want in the list.
problems.task: Modify the list to print the numbers 5, 10, and 15.
problems.hint: Change the numbers inside the square brackets [].

problems.title: Indentation matters!
problems.content:
In Python, indentation (the spaces at the beginning of lines) is very important. It tells Python which lines belong inside the loop.

Think of it like a recipe. The for loop is like a heading, for example 'To make the icing:', and all the indented lines are the steps that belong to that heading.
problems.task:
First run the code and notice how many times 'and' is printed.

Instead we want to output
1
and
2
and
3
and

Add spaces in front of the second print statement so that it lines up perfectly under the first one.
problems.hint: Both print statements should have the same indentation (2 spaces) to be inside the loop. The second print statement needs to be indented like the first one.

problems.title: Write your first loop
problems.content: Now it's your turn to write a loop from the beginning.
problems.task: Write a for loop that prints the numbers 1, 3, and 5.
problems.hint: Start with for num in [1, 3, 5]: and then add the print statement on the next line.

rules.message: Your code needs to use a 'for' loop

problems.title: Looping over words
problems.content: Lists can hold words (strings) too, not just numbers.
problems.task: Run the code to see how the loop prints each word from the list.
problems.hint: The word variable will be 'I', then 'am', then 'learning'.

problems.title: A shortcut: range()
problems.content: Typing out long lists of numbers is boring. The range() function is a shortcut to create a sequence of numbers.
problems.task: Run this code. Notice that range(5) creates numbers from 0 up to 4.
problems.hint: Programmers often start counting from 0!

problems.title: Modify the range
problems.content: You can change the number inside range() to create a longer or shorter sequence.
problems.task: Edit the code to print the numbers from 0 up to 9.
problems.hint: What number should you put inside range() to get 10 numbers (0 to 9)? The range() function stops before the number you give it, so you always need to go one number higher than the last number you want.

problems.title: Write a loop with range
problems.content: Let's practice writing a loop with range() from scratch.
problems.task: Write a program that prints the numbers from 0 up to 6.
problems.hint: You'll need range(7) to get numbers from 0 to 6.

rules.message: Your code needs to use a 'for' loop
Your code needs to use the 'range()' function

problems.title: Setting a start point
problems.content: range() can also take a starting number. range(1, 6) starts at 1 and ends at 5.
problems.task: Run the code to see how it prints numbers from 1 to 5.
problems.hint: The first number is where to start, the second number is where to stop (before reaching it).

problems.title: Modify the start and stop
problems.content: You can choose any start and stop point you like.
problems.task: Edit the range() to print the numbers from 5 up to 10.
problems.hint: The range should be range(5, 11) to include 10.

rules.message: Your code needs to use the 'range()' function

problems.title: Write your own range
problems.content: Practice makes perfect! Write another loop with a start and stop.
problems.task: Write a program that prints all the whole numbers from 10 to 20.
problems.hint: Remember, the stop number needs to be one higher than the last number you want.

rules.message: Your code needs to use a 'for' loop
Your code needs to use the 'range()' function

problems.title: Creating patterns
problems.content: Loops are great for drawing simple patterns. In Python, multiplying a string (like '*') by a number repeats it.
problems.task: Run the code to draw a simple triangle.
problems.starterCode:
for i in range(1, 6):
  print('*' * i)
problems.hint: First the loop prints one star, then two, then three, and so on.

problems.title: Modify the pattern
problems.content: You can use any character to create your pattern.
problems.task: Change the character from a star * to a hash #.
problems.starterCode:
for i in range(1, 6):
  print('*' * i)
problems.hint: Just replace the * inside the print() function.

problems.title: Summing numbers
problems.content: Loops can be used to add up a list of numbers. We use a variable (here, total) to keep track of the sum as we go.
problems.task: Run this code to calculate the sum of numbers from 1 to 5.
problems.starterCode:
total = 0
for i in range(1, 6):
  total = total + i
print(total)
problems.hint: Watch how total grows with each loop: 0+1=1, then 1+2=3, then 3+3=6, and so on.

problems.title: Challenge: Interactive sum calculator
problems.content: Let's make our summing program interactive.
problems.task:
Ask the user for a number n, then calculate the sum of all numbers from 1 to n.

Try different user inputs and calculate the sums yourself to see where your code might be going wrong. For example, if the user enters 3, the output should be 1+2+3=6.
problems.hint: You need a loop that uses range(1, n + 1), and a variable like 'total' to keep track of the sum.

rules.message: Your code needs to use a 'for' loop
Your code needs to use the 'range()' function

rules.solutionCode:
n = get_input()
total = 0
for i in range(1, n + 1):
  total = total + i
print(total)

problems.title: Challenge: The Product
problems.content: Multiplying a series of numbers is called finding the 'product'.
problems.task: Modify this summing code to instead find the product of numbers from 1 to 5. What happens if total starts at 0?
problems.starterCode:
total = 0
for i in range(1, 6):
  total = total + i
print(total)
problems.hint: The task asks what happens if total starts at 0. After you change the + to a *, try running it to see the problem for yourself. What must the starting value be so that multiplying by it doesn't always result in zero?

rules.message: Your code needs to use a 'for' loop

problems.title: Creative challenge
problems.content: Now it's your turn to be creative! Use loops and inputs to build something interesting.
problems.task: Create a program that takes at least one number as input and uses a for loop to do something cool. It could be a pattern, calculator, countdown, or something else. Show your teacher!
problems.hint: What could you do with the two user inputs? What happens with a loop inside a loop?
